list_definition.definition: a machine with a long arm and a chain, for raising heavy weights

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The crates are lifted by crane onto a truck.

list_definition.definition: to stretch out (the neck, to see round or over something)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He craned his neck in order to see round the corner.

list_ex_of_english: There is a mixture of the most modern cranes and motor lorries being used to handle the traffic, alongside horses and simple manhandling.
We are now fitting our ships, for example, with much more powerful cranes and derricks to enable them to handle abnormal lifts, such as tanks.
I asked about safety and skill training and, specifically, about training in the use of cranes, vehicles, forklifts and so on.
We want to ensure that the cranes shall be replaced by the most modern available, which frankly, could not go on the existing quay.
Most sites going to high building in this country now have tower cranes and use all sorts of other advanced management techniques as well.
One of the worst industries in the world for accidents are cranes.
They are cranes which can move only under their own steam.
I happen to know that there are from this country working in other countries large numbers of operative engineers, constructing cranes and various other things.
